guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

post.body: Do you suppose that Christ would have approved of His disciples killing with the sword in reference to Luke 22:36
post.body_html: Do you suppose that Christ would have approved of His disciples killing with the sword in reference to Luke 22:36
post.title: Do you think Christ taught self-defense by violent/lethal means?

body:
ahhh good catch - although I suppose I could try to extend the argument then that the early to current Christians would have approved of what John said (otherwise if not they would have attacked this as an error, right?)

the [Catholic view / encyclopedia entry on self-defense](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/13691a.htm) says:

> Everyone has the right to defend his life against the attacks of an unjust aggressor. For this end he may employ whatever force is necessary and even take the life of an unjust assailant. As bodily integrity is included in the good of life, it may be defended in the same way as life itself. It must be observed however that no more injury may be inflicted on the assailant than is necessary to defeat his purpose. If, for example, he can be driven off by a call for help or by inflicting a slight wound on him, he may not lawfully be slain. 

> Again the unjust attack must be actually begun, at least morally speaking, not merely planned or intended for some future time or occasion. generally speaking one is not bound to preserve one's own life at the expense of the assailant's; one may, out of charity, forego one's right in the matter. Sometimes, however, one may be bound to defend one's own life to the utmost on account of one's duty of state or other obligations. The life of another person may be defended on the same conditions by us as our own. For since each person has the right to defend his life unjustly attacked, what he can lawfully do through his own efforts he may also do through the agency of others. 

> Sometimes, too, charity, natural affection, or official duty imposed the obligation of defending others. A father ought, for example, to defend the lives of his children; a husband, his wife; and all ought to defend the life of one whose death would be a serious loss to the community. Soldiers, policemen, and private guards hired for that purpose are bound in justice to safeguard the lives of those entrusted to them.

> It is lawful to defend one's material goods even at the expense of the agressor's life; for neither justice nor charity require that one should sacrifice possessions, even though they be of less value than human life in order to preserve the life of a man who wantonly exposes it in order to do an injustice. Here, however, we must recall the principle that in extreme necessity every man has a right to appropriate whatever is necessary to preserve his life.
body_html:
ahhh good catch - although I suppose I could try to extend the argument then that the early to current Christians would have approved of what John said (otherwise if not they would have attacked this as an error, right?)

the Catholic view / encyclopedia entry on self-defense says:

Everyone has the right to defend his life against the attacks of an unjust aggressor. For this end he may employ whatever force is necessary and even take the life of an unjust assailant. As bodily integrity is included in the good of life, it may be defended in the same way as life itself. It must be observed however that no more injury may be inflicted on the assailant than is necessary to defeat his purpose. If, for example, he can be driven off by a call for help or by inflicting a slight wound on him, he may not lawfully be slain.

Again the unjust attack must be actually begun, at least morally speaking, not merely planned or intended for some future time or occasion. generally speaking one is not bound to preserve one's own life at the expense of the assailant's; one may, out of charity, forego one's right in the matter. Sometimes, however, one may be bound to defend one's own life to the utmost on account of one's duty of state or other obligations. The life of another person may be defended on the same conditions by us as our own. For since each person has the right to defend his life unjustly attacked, what he can lawfully do through his own efforts he may also do through the agency of others.

Sometimes, too, charity, natural affection, or official duty imposed the obligation of defending others. A father ought, for example, to defend the lives of his children; a husband, his wife; and all ought to defend the life of one whose death would be a serious loss to the community. Soldiers, policemen, and private guards hired for that purpose are bound in justice to safeguard the lives of those entrusted to them.

It is lawful to defend one's material goods even at the expense of the agressor's life; for neither justice nor charity require that one should sacrifice possessions, even though they be of less value than human life in order to preserve the life of a man who wantonly exposes it in order to do an injustice. Here, however, we must recall the principle that in extreme necessity every man has a right to appropriate whatever is necessary to preserve his life.

author.bio:
Faith, Hope, and Love is the path to Life, Liberty, and Happiness.

There is no justification for any human authority.
author.bio_html:
Faith, Hope, and Love is the path to Life, Liberty, and Happiness.

There is no justification for any human authority.

body:
In my understanding, the early church excommunicated those who joined armies of their nations, especially the roman army... and it wasn't until Constantine and the battle of Milvian bridge that joining ranks was considered ok.  They'd even excommunicate the cohortes urbanae.

I think once the state adopted Christianity, violence was acceptable.

I've no doubt that Catholics and other denomination justify using lethal means as self defense as they could justify anything to suit their order... but when I observe the actions of Christ - He never engaged in a retributive act of defense, rather, he took it or healed the aggressor or rebuked them verbally.
body_html:
In my understanding, the early church excommunicated those who joined armies of their nations, especially the roman army... and it wasn't until Constantine and the battle of Milvian bridge that joining ranks was considered ok. They'd even excommunicate the cohortes urbanae.

I think once the state adopted Christianity, violence was acceptable.

I've no doubt that Catholics and other denomination justify using lethal means as self defense as they could justify anything to suit their order... but when I observe the actions of Christ - He never engaged in a retributive act of defense, rather, he took it or healed the aggressor or rebuked them verbally.

body:
> the early church excommunicated those who joined armies of their nations, especially the roman army

I'd have to look in to this but it could be because they required worship of false idols, not necessarily because they opposed the government or police or military

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diocletianic_Persecution

parent.body:
In my understanding, the early church excommunicated those who joined armies of their nations, especially the roman army... and it wasn't until Constantine and the battle of Milvian bridge that joining ranks was considered ok.  They'd even excommunicate the cohortes urbanae.

I think once the state adopted Christianity, violence was acceptable.

I've no doubt that Catholics and other denomination justify using lethal means as self defense as they could justify anything to suit their order... but when I observe the actions of Christ - He never engaged in a retributive act of defense, rather, he took it or healed the aggressor or rebuked them verbally.
parent.body_html:
In my understanding, the early church excommunicated those who joined armies of their nations, especially the roman army... and it wasn't until Constantine and the battle of Milvian bridge that joining ranks was considered ok. They'd even excommunicate the cohortes urbanae.

I think once the state adopted Christianity, violence was acceptable.

I've no doubt that Catholics and other denomination justify using lethal means as self defense as they could justify anything to suit their order... but when I observe the actions of Christ - He never engaged in a retributive act of defense, rather, he took it or healed the aggressor or rebuked them verbally.
